1.title: Unknown Lady
1.sitter_text: Unknown Lady (perhaps of the Vavasour family)
1.description_content: Isaac Oliver's portrait of a fashionably attired unknown lady depicts a young, stylishly attired woman, with a black hat and a profusion of white lace and pearls. She has long been considered a ‘typical’ example of this artist's work.
1.description_physical:
The ultraviolet (UV) image of this work shows that numerous areas have been retouched. These include portions of her hat and black costume, which display a greenish fluorescence under UV illumination, indicative of the presence of modern pigments, such as zinc white (as confirmed by additional X-ray fluorescence [XRF] analysis). Extensive repainting can also be identified throughout the white passages of the costume.

The white overpainting appears to be covering dull grey (original) paint, whose muted colour must have been the reason for the extensive intervention. This grey pigment has been identified as calomel, which was probably white initially, but exposure to light or possibly alkali turned it grey, thus making necessary the extensive repainting.
1.pigments_costume: Dress: bone black, lead white, vermilion, bone black (retouching), zinc white (retouching), indigo (retouching); lace: calomel/mercury white (retouch: barium sulphate); ruff:  barium sulphate (retouching), calcium-based compound (retouching)
1.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, vermilion, red lead; lips: red lead, vermilion, pink lake
1.pigments_hair_and_beard: Carbon-based black, red lead, lead white, yellow earth pigments

49.title: A lady (b. c. 1567)
49.description_content: This miniature shows a lady wearing a capotain hat with a rounded crown and her right hand placed on her hip. She is depicted in a three-quarter length format--an unusual format for portrait miniatures that tend to show sitters in half-length or bust-length formats. It is one of the earliest known attributable to Isaac Oliver, with an inscription in gold that reads 'Anno Domini 1587, aetatis suae 20'. While the costume is 'just' black, Oliver put great care into the modelling, using two different blacks to achieve subtle differences in hue and saturation by mixing in tiny amounts of lead-tin yellow, lead white and small, and he has used tiny shell-silver dots (now tarnished to black) to detail the hat brim and the zigzag pattern on the hat ribbon, which can still be seen in the micrograph detail of the hat.
49.description_physical:
The UV image shows retouching evident in the flesh tones, white shirt and ruff. It appears of greenish colour under UV light and is associated with the use of zinc white.  
The palette identified is consistent with the materials employed by Isaac Oliver. However, the use of smalt and lead-tin yellow in different parts of the black dress and a lead-tin yellow base layer under gilding is unusual.
The original back of the miniature was not accessible, but a vermilion detail, probably a seal, is evident in the MA-XRF-generated mercury distribution map and in the x-ray. The x-ray also shows that the positioning of the proper right hand may have been altered, moving the hand further back than initially planned.
49.pigments_costume: Dress: bone black, lead white, lead-tin yellow, smalt; ruff: lead white (retouch: zinc white); pink ribbon: lead white, pink lake
49.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead (retouch: zinc white); lips: red lake
49.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, lead white, carbon black
49.pigments_jewellery: Gold (yellow layer underneath: lead-tin yellow type I)

50.title: A lady, called Frances Walsingham, Countess of Essex (b.1550)
50.sitter_text: A lady, called Frances Walsingham, Countess of Essex
50.description_content: A young woman depicted in a highly elaborate costume and standing ruff with extensive lace-detailing. The white dress and lace were set off with copious strokes of shell-silver to indicate highlights on pearls and jewels, but also imitating silver-thread embroidery on the bodice, which has now tarnished to black. While the miniature is highly worked and would have initially glittered when held and moved as a result of the shell silver applications catching the light, it has an otherwise restrained palette that would have set off the very fair complexion of the sitter.
50.description_physical:
The dark grey background painted with bone black and possibly an organic dye is an unusual choice among the Isaac Oliver's miniatures analysed.
The UV image clearly shows retouching in the flesh tones and the background and outlining of the white detailing in the dress; the bright UV fluorescence indicates the use of zinc white for the extensive retouching. The miniature has suffered from the loss of many of its silver highlights on pearls and jewellery, and of the bodied daubs of lead white siting beneath. The best preserved shell silver passage is the star-shaped pendant, where the silver sits on top of gold. Mercury, possibly in the form of quicksilver, occurs simultaneously with the silver and could suggest the use of an amalgam.
50.pigments_costume: Dress: lead white (zinc white for retouching); ruff: lead white, indigo (for shading)
50.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead; lips: red lead, vermilion, red dye
50.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, lead white, umber pigment (dark passages)

51.title: A lady, called Lady Arabella Stuart (1575-1615)
51.sitter_text: A lady, called Lady Arabella Stuart (1575-1615)
51.description_content: A well-preserved portrait of a young female sitter with her long, curly hair hanging loose behind her shoulders. She is wearing an embroidered  bodice with low décolletage, a pearl and gold earring, a pearl choker with a large diamond and pearl-studded gold pendant suspended from a black string, and a long, black string necklace disappearing behind the lace-edged trim of the bodice. Her costume bears a strong resemblance with those worn by several female sitters by portrait painter William Larkin (active 1609-19) and his followers, such as Isabella Rich, Mrs. Rogers (1614-18), Jane, Lady Thornaugh (1617) and portraits of Frances Howard, Duchess of Richmond and Lennox.
51.description_physical:
The miniatures appears to be in a good state of preservation. Under UV light, no retouching is evident. 
Some features and material choices are unusual when compared to other Oliver miniatures. For instance, the white lace containing lead-tin yellow to achieve a warmer tone when painted over the dress, in contrast to the pure lead white lace painted over the flesh tones. The warm yellow base of the pendant contains lead-tin yellow with further reddish-brown detailing, which is also uncommon for Oliver. The presence of copper chlorides identified in the greens has never been identified in other Oliver's miniatures.
51.pigments_costume: Lead white, azurite (blue flowers), red lead (orange flowers), red lake (pink flowers), lead tin yellow and copper chlorides (green flowers), lead tin yellow type I (yellow flowers), organic green? (dark green stem); ruff: lead white, lead tin yellow
51.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead, chalk; lips: red lead, red lake
51.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, lead white, gypsum, lead tin yellow

52.title: John Donne (1573-1631)
52.description_content: This miniature of John Donne is likely to be a copy after the version in the Royal Collection (RCIN 420026), also featured on this website.
52.description_physical:
The miniature has been retouched with smalt in the background and zinc white in the collar. This could indicate two different campaigns of intervention.
Technically, in comparison with the version in the Royal Collection (RCIN 420026), it is executed quite differently. It lacks the controlled stippling technique and the precise modelling of the original. Materially, there is a great deal of overlaps with RCIN 420026, however vermilion, used in the lips, is only present in this version and appears not to have been part of the palette of RCIN 420026.
52.pigments_costume: Doublet: carbon black,earth pigment, copper-based pigment, lead white (for highlights); ruff: lead white, copper-based pigment (shading)
52.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead, lead-tin yellow; lips: red lead, vermilion
52.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, lead-based pigment, carbon black?

53.title: A young girl
53.artist_text: Issac Oliver; later additions by Unknown
53.description_content:
This miniature has either been left unfinished, or was intended as a studio pattern deliberately done in a sketchy fashion (other surviving versions are not known). The heavy dark outlines of the hair-ornaments, the cursory yet informative setting out of the dress features, and the lack of modelling to the face, may indicate the latter, as finished miniatures would not typically feature the relatively heavy-handed daubs and black outlining at the early stages of execution, since these would be difficult to disguise later on in the painting process using gum-bound pigments on vellum. 

It has been embellished at a later point, in particular with reinforcements to the figure-of-eight lines of the collar drawn up with zinc white, pointing to a C19th or C20th intervention.
53.description_physical: The UV image shows pink UV fluorescence in the background, corresponding to the use of a red organic dye, and a pale orange fluorescence on the ruff and dress indicate  the presence of lead white. Some zinc-based retouching, appearing bright green under UV light, is evident on the ruff. Silver, now tarnished to black, was used for the black line pattern on the sleeve.
53.pigments_costume: Dress: lead white, carbon black (shading), azurite (blue detailing); ruff: lead white, copper-based pigment, zinc white (retouch), cobalt blue (retouch); headdress: azurite, yellow ochre
53.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white; lips: red organic dye

54.title: Thomas, 3rd and last Viscount Howard of Bindon (d.1610)
54.sitter_text: Thomas, 3rd and last Viscount Howard of Bindon
54.description_content: While technically different to Isaac Oliver's miniatures, the purple background situates this miniature in the 17th century when this colour was introduced for portrait miniature backgrounds.
54.description_physical: The pigment selection found in this miniature are wholly consistent with those available in the period of Isaac Oliver's active years, with the exception of the inscription in the background, which appears to be  brass-based, and was not used by Oliver.
54.pigments_background: Red organic dye (insect-based), indigo, lead white, azurite, bone black
54.pigments_costume: Doublet: bone black, indigo, azurite (slashes); ruff: lead white, indigo
54.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, carbon black, red lead, earth pigment (ear); lips: vermilion
54.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, lead white, bone black

56.title: Jane Boughton, née Coningsby (b. 1553)
56.description_physical:
The palette identified is compatible with the materials available to Hilliard.
UV image: the flesh tone appears bright white, due to the fluorescence of the parchment underneath; the orange UV fluorescence colour is associated to the use of lead white. 
The verso of the playing card was analysed: red areas: vermilion; dark and blue areas: indigo; green area: indigo and likely a yellow dye; yellow areas: yellow dye(?); purple areas: red/ purple dye(?)
56.pigments_costume: White shirt and ruff: lead white; black bodice: bone black; headdress: earth pigments, bone black, lead-based pigments

56.pigments_jewellery: Silver; gold (orange underlayer: earth pigments and arsenic sulphides)

63.title: Portrait of William Drummond of Hawthornden (c. 1615)
63.description_physical:
The UV image shows limited retouching on the white ruff and flesh areas: the retouching appears bright yellow in UV which is usually associated with the presence of zinc white. The dull orange UV fluorescence colour evident on the ruff is instead due to the use of lead white, and is original. A dark red/maroon UV fluorescence colour on the background is likely due to the use of a red lake and indigo.

The x-ray image highlights the wood grain of the support onto which the miniature is laid. 
This image is also particularly useful in this case because it reveals the presence of an upside-down heart  in the area of the sitter's face. This symbol is present on the playing card, the back of which remains inaccessible due to the framing of this object. The MA-XRF analysis suggests that this heart was executed using vermilion.
63.pigments_costume: Doublet: bone black, carbon black, lead white; white ruff: lead white, azurite (shading), zinc white (retouching)
63.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, chalk, red lead(?), earth pigment(?), barium white (retouching); lips: red lake, red lead(?)
63.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth and umber pigments, chalk, lead-based pigment, lead-tin yellow, carbon black(?)

65.title: George Clifford (1558-1605), 3rd Earl of Cumberland, Admiral
65.sitter_text: George Clifford (1558-1605), 3rd Earl of Cumberland, Admiral
65.description_physical:
The raking light image shows the floating-in technique used to paint the background around the sitter's figure. Under UV, the miniature seems to be in a good state of preservation, with some colour losses around the border, which appear bright white due to the fluorescence of the parchment. The orange UV fluorescence displayed by the collar suggests the use of lead white in this area, whereas the pinkish colour of the lips indicates the presence of a red organic dye.
The blue background appears dark in the NIR image, due to the use of a copper-based pigment (azurite), as well as the black doublet and hat due to the presence of carbon-based black pigments. A faint hatching is evident around the border of the background, likely made with a different blue pigment.
The flesh tones are painted with a small amount of lead white, as evident in the x-ray image because they appear dark. The doublet and hat also appear dark, but the modelling with lead white is evident in the doublet, which appear moderately grey.
65.pigments_costume: Black doublet: bone black, lead white; white collar: lead white, azurite; black hat: bone black, carbon black
65.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead(?), vermilion (for outlining the features); lips: red lead(?)
65.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, carbon black(?), lead white(?)

66.title: George Clifford (1558-1605), 3rd Earl of Cumberland, Admiral
66.sitter_text: George Clifford (1558-1605), 3rd Earl of Cumberland, Admiral
66.description_physical:
The raking light shows the floating-in technique for the background, applied around the sitter's head and beard. Some colour losses are evident around the border. 
Under UV, the collar, costume and small details in the eyes show a bright red UV fluorescence, characteristic of mercury white. The miniature appears retouched around the border, especially at the top and left side, and on the sash area; the bright yellow UV fluorescence suggests the use of zinc white.
Blue and green areas appear dark in the NIR image, suggesting the use of copper-based pigments. In particular, the retouched areas in the background are distinguishable from the original paint passage because they appear darker; one single area at the top left is transparent to the IR radiation, indicating a different blue pigment from the one used for the original background or the repainting.
The flesh tones are painted with a small amount of lead white, as evident from the x-ray image and the dark area corresponding to flesh tones and hair. An heavy element, identified by XRF as mercury, is used in the costume, collar and eyes, which appear white. Part of the costume is black because it was left unpainted, and brushstrokes of white pigments are roughly applied. The background and sash also appear moderately white, due to the use of copper in this case. Colour losses appearing dark are evident in the background and around the border.
66.pigments_costume: Doublet: lead white, calomel/mercury white; blue flowers: azurite; orange flowers: red lead; pink flowers: red lake; green leaves: mineral copper green, yellow dye(?); deep blue sash: azurite, red organic dye; collar: lead white, calomel/mercury white
66.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead, vermilion; lips: red lead(?)
66.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, calomel/vermilion, lead-based pigment, carbon black(?)

84.title: Anne of Denmark
84.description_physical:
Some details in the hair ornaments, brooches and pendant contain brass.
Under UV light, the miniature appears heavily retouched. Areas with a yellow-green UV fluorescence, such as the pearls and portions of the ruff, are retouched with zinc white. Orange parts are lead white retouchings?? 
The red background has a reddish UV fluorescence, characterisc of red lakes. 
Green and blue areas appear dark in the NIR image, suggesting the use of copper-based pigments. The shaded area of the ruff is also dark to the NIR radiation, likely due to the use of carbon black to shade the portion.
The x-ray highlights the use of metals and lead-based pigments (lead white and red lead), which appear bright in the image. The flesh tones are painted with only a small amount of lead white.
84.pigments_costume: Dress: lead white, copper sulphate, azurite; orange ribbon: red lead, red lake; pink ribbon: pink lake, vermilion; white collar: lead white, zinc white (retouching)
84.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead(?), pink dye (modelling on the cheeks); lips: red lead(?), pink lake
84.pigments_jewellery: Gold; silver; blue cross pendant: azurite, zinc white (retouching), barium white (retouching), Prussian blue (retouching), brass

85.title: Charles I as a Child, King of England Scotland and Ireland
85.description_physical:
Under UV and raking light, the miniature appears in a good state of preservation, and no retouchings are evident. The red background and pink lips show a reddish UV fluorescence, indicating the use of red lakes. White areas that appear orange under UV, such as the collar and eyes, are painted with lead white.
Blue and green areas appear dark in the NIR region, suggesting the presence of copper-based pigments. The shading part of the collar also appears dark, indicating the use of carbon black to make this area grey.
The x-ray image highlights the use of heavy elements, such as lead, that appear brighter. A round shape painted with an heavy element, identified with XRF as mercury, is also evident at the centre of the miniature, but it belongs to the playing card used as support. The flesh tones and hair appear painted with a very small amount of lead-based pigments.
The vermilion distribution linked to the playing card could suggest that a figure card was used.
85.pigments_costume: White and green doublet: lead white, carbon black (shading), copper-based green (sulphate?), lead-tin yellow (layer under green); blue ribbon: azurite, ultramarine; white collar: lead white, azurite, carbon black (grey area)
85.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead(?), red earth pigment (outlines of the facial features); lips: red lead, red dye
85.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, carbon black(?), lead white(?)

105.title: A party in the open air. Allegory on conjugal love
105.description_physical:
The flesh tones contain a mixture of lead white and red lead; on the male sitters' flesh tones investigated, there is an addition of hematite and likely pararealgar.
A number of green pigments have been identified, often mixed together to create the foliage of trees. Brochantite is found in the bluish areas of foliage, landscape, and some clothing, while malachite has been used as a bright green on foliage and landscape. A mixture of azurite and indigo is found in green grass and bushes, likely with the addition of a yellow component (not earth pigments).
A lipid binder, associated with egg yolk or oil, is identified by FTIR in passages with black, red (vermilion) and copper-based green pigments. Calcium oxalate was also identified on several areas.
105.pigments_background: Blue background: azurite; grey landscape: smalt; green leaves: brochantite, azurite, malachite, indigo, chrome green (retouching); yellow foliage: lead-tin yellow, lead white, massicot; red foliage: vermilion; brown trunks: earth pigments, bone black
105.pigments_costume: Black costumes: bone black; white ruffs: lead white; orange costumes: red lead; pink costumes: red organic dyes; lilac/cangiante dress: red organic dye, azurite; yellow costumes: lead-tin yellow, yellow earth; blue parts: azurite, brochantite
105.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead, hematite, pararealgar
